statement: I believe everyone should be able to see a doctor and get basic medical care without going broke, but I don’t think a one-size-fits-all government-run system is the answer. The government’s role should be to set fair rules, prevent people from being denied coverage for preexisting conditions, and provide a safety net for those who truly can’t afford care, while still relying on private insurers and competition to keep quality high and costs in check.

A public safety net is important so no one is left without essential care, yet private doctors, hospitals, and insurance should remain the main providers, with competition to keep costs in check. The government’s role should be to regulate fairly, prevent abuse, and help those who truly can’t pay, not to run everything or take away people’s choices.

I believe the government should guarantee universal access to basic healthcare, including preventive and rehabilitative services, through a system like a public option or expanded Medicare, while still allowing private plans for those who want them. Healthcare is a fundamental public good, and a wealthy country has a moral and practical obligation to ensure that people’s ability to move, work, and live without avoidable pain isn’t determined by their income or employment status.

statement: As someone who spent her life as a nurse, I’ve seen too many good people delay care because they couldn’t afford it, and that’s simply wrong in a country with our resources. I believe the government has a responsibility to guarantee universal access to healthcare, funded fairly through taxes, so that everyone—no matter their age, income, or job—can see a doctor, get their medicines, and receive hospital care without fear of financial ruin. A strong public system can still work alongside private options, but the basic promise of care should not depend on your wallet.

statement: I think the government should make sure everyone can get basic healthcare, because nobody deserves to get really sick or die just because their family doesn’t have enough money. My family has insurance, but I know not everyone does, and that doesn’t seem fair, especially for little kids. The government should at least cover essential stuff like checkups, emergency care, and medicine, and then people who want more can pay for extra through private options.
